Oh boy, where do I begin?
Half Life, such an iconic game to me and so close to my heart, being one of the first real games I enjoyed playing and went back and finished numerous times. In my opinion it's one of the best games of the 20th Century, and dare I say it, of all time (and I'm sure many will agree with me).

The quirky characters and voices, the repeated models of scientists and cheesy lines are some of what makes this game brilliant, as well as the enemies, the weapons, the plot and the idea that you're one with this game, experiencing it all. For at the time of Valve being such a small organisation, this was a hell of a good job at a game.

I'd highly recommend anyone to play this game, whether you're a CoD hardcore fan or a Minecraft fan, this game is worth a shot. Many may not like this for the poor graphics in comparison to modern gaming (this was out in 1998!), but this is one of the games that needs to teach players to love the storyline more than the graphics, and is a brilliant way to get younger gamers to appreciate games like this.
Best game ever made.

Half-Life is a game from "life" series that includes for example "second life". In 0.5-Life you play as Gordian Firmman who is a scientist working at Black Nasa research facility. One day scientists are doing some test in which you are forced to do very dangerous, simple task that obviously robot could perform even more accurately, though you are proably not very liked by your supervisors, your next task would be proably testing new anti-personell mines by walking on them.
Anyway during test something goes wrong (I bet it's bug that valve forgotten to fix before release) and it leads to resonance echo wave reverberance pulsative reaction cascade (as you can see it was completely unforeseeable consequence) which open portals to science fiction dimension and brings aliens (proably those ancient ones history channel keeps talking about) to earth. And as if that wasn't enough those stupid grunts from the marines (that were sent to facility to kill everyone because why not) want to show you their war face and prevent you from becoming a free man. Fortunately though after graduating from MIT and spending years studying quantum physics your war face is beyond comprehension of these stupid, mechanicaly thinking, proably supporting copenhagen interpretation of quantum physics grunts which results in their literal extinction. Later during your surreal journey remaining scientists inform you that you have to meet scientists at lambda department of black nasa because for some reason they are the only people that can save world in this situation (why I don't really remember, but considering that lambda is logo of the game I guess it needs to be somehow tied to its story) So you go and meet them and without any waste of time they force you to jump into some portal (but not too early, firmman you fool!) which transports you into shadow realm where you have to... well you don't really know what you have to do, but somehow you manage to find some fancy level transitions that lead you to some of the worst levels you will ever play in this game. What else to add? Well during your stroll through black mesa you will discover that scientists there were also working on sophisticated torture methods (*cough* on rail *cough*) and you will also frequently encounter very mysterious man in a suit with flat head and suitcase who is very mysterious and important to the game (or rather iconic, because no one really knows why is he important and devs never bothered to explain it, instead they wrote famous scenes with him and made him speak quotes that even your grandkids will know)
So as you can see 1/2-Life is game worthy of playing and replaying, though I hope one time they gonna fix that resonance avalanchescade bug that always sends you to unforeseen consequence chapter and forces you to play accident% route.
You don't need to hear this, you're a trained professional.

Não sou nenhum fã das antigas nem joguei isso quando era pequeno, comprei por saber que era um grande título por que o preço estava ótimo(rsrsrsrs). Eu sempre gostei mais das histórias que dos gráficos por isso não liguei pelo gráfico ser ultapassado, o jogo tem uma estória muito interessante para quem gosta um pouco de sci-fi como eu, e deveria ser um título obrigatorio para os grandes fãs do gênero, o gameplay é muito divertido, e dependendo de como você jogue pode ser muito dinâmico,e o jogo também é bom em lhe dar pequenos sustos pelo ambiente decandente da black mesa... 

Resumindo, se você gosta de sci-fi ou fps, esse jogo pode ser excelente para você.
epic

One of the greatest games of all time. In 1998 Half-Life took everything that was great about the FPS and revolutionised the genre in a way Half-Life 2 did in terms of story-telling in 2004.

The graphics don't hold up well in terms of today's standards, however the gameplay, story, and AI certaintly do. The story whilst cliched was told in a revolutionary way, showing how a story could be done in games without the need for cutscenes and thereby allowing full player immersion. The gameplay never stays the same and showed other developers how to vary the gameplay in each stage, introducing new weapons/enemies, allowing you time to experiment before unleashing a number of enemies at you. The latter stages of the game are a bit of a let-down in comparison to what came before, but it barely detracts from an awesome game.

The AI holds up just as well as the gameplay and story. The aliens are standard fare, but know when to charge and when to hold back if injured. It is in the Marines that you encounter where the AI shines through. The Marines know how to flank, take cover, throw grenades to get you out of cover, place traps when running away, and fall back when injured. Rarely will you encounter AI as intelligent in most modern games.

If you want to play a game that many recognise as revolutionary in 1998 and had a profound effect on the games you play today then play Half-Life.

Menuda joya! La verdad es que a veces los juegos antiguos me producen una desesperación por querer acabarlos rapido porque llega un punto en el que son predecibles. Sin embargo, Hal Life me ha cautivado completamente, su narración y dificultad en ciertos momentos me hicieron pasar un rato muy agradable. Gran juego que no debería pasarse por alto!

Half-Life is one of the best FPS games of it's time. It was one of the few to have a good plot, even if it was not very large one. It has no in game cut-scenes so a plot twist can happen at any time. Deep underground in the Black Mesa Research Facility, a secret project is underway. A portal to a other world has been opened, and human tech has never seen anything like it. You are Gordan Freeman, a young associate in Anomalous Materials Lab. You have limted security clearance and no real idea how dangerous your job is about to become, until you are sent alone into the test chamber. Untill something goes wrong. Is it damaged? An accident? Or is it something you did? All you hear is people screaming; all you see is space time gone. the next thing you see Black Mesa Research Facility is a nightmare.
Very good game, aproved by sloths, favorite game, would buy again, I don't need more words to tell how good is Half-Life.

If Quake nudged the FPS genre into the mainstream, Half-Life attached a rocket propulsion system to it.

Como o primeiro da franquia, sua história, mesmo com a falta de opções gráficas da época que foi desenvolvido, conseguiu ser uma história extremamente boa e cativante. A imersão que o jogador consegue jogando Half-Life é simplesmente única. Incorporando Gordon Freeman, um cientista da Facilidade Black Mesa, que não fala se quer uma palavra no jogo. O fato de sua lacuna de comunicação faz com que o jogador se sinta cada vez mais dentro do personagem, muitas vezes até pensando como ele. E sem contar que o fato de matar aliens deixa o jogo ainda mais cativante, e o fato de Freeman causar e conter o problema, consegue fazer com que ele se torne um personagem incrível de ser vivido.

I mean it's soooooooooooooooooo EMPTY at least compared to the rest of the game that is... still worth every cent to play this again.

My favorite game of all time. Main reasons are...
#1 - Movement. You can control your movement so good and you can go so fast and precisely it's wonderful. Best movement there has ever been in a video game.
#2 - Story. Good length, with good amount of difficulty and you clearly know what has/is happening.
#3 and final big reason is the multiplayer. It's still alive and there are many servers. Multiplayer has a great skill-gap and you recognize a l337 and n00b just by looking at their movement for 4 seconds.

This game, is just plain AWESOME. Even though it was released in 98', The graphics were pretty ahead of its time. Also the story behind it, with its sci-fi story and outline, mixed with a little horror sci-fi, aswell as its counter part story sequal in Half-Life 2, (and maybe soon to be Half-Life 3). This Game is still very fun to play, even a decade after its release. 

I would recommend this game.

What a privilege it is for you if you have finished this game. Half-Life sits in a chair in a vast and golden hall along with only the highlords of the first-person-shooting genre. There we can find the likes of DooM, Wolfenstein, Quake, Unreal, BioShock, GoldenEye, Battlefield 2... Yes, Half-Life is that noble.

Gordon Freeman is a physicist gone survivor/gunslinger in chaotic circumstances surrounding the accidental opening of a dimensional portal that brought about alien hostile presence into the Black Mesa Research Facility. The tension can be felt through every sensorial fibre of the narrative, from the stable low-pitch melodies of the soundtrack to the sudden appearances of creatures throughout the many corridors and laboratories found in the maps. The level design is extraordinary, and intelligent in progressively revealing the labyrinthine network of tunnels and ducts that hide vital items for the adequate fast-paced action of a quintessential shooter. However, such a network also provides the player with the strategic edge to approach danger and conflict, something innovative in itself for a genre that is - usually - sadly stigmatised by the shortcomings of linearity.

Its daring features are a testament to the prime product of an age that it was. Half-Life subtly overcomes limitations of its time: it pioneered non-cutscene dynamic action and continuous immersive narrative, allowing the player to actually be part of everything s/he watches from behind the screen. Gordon may never be seen or heard in the de facto game, but the initial display of routine in Black Mesa (the famous tram sequence) drowns the player in unsullied immersion, not presenting any perspective bias or character automation. Gordon Freeman is as "free" a protagonist as it gets in a game of this kind.

Be it for the strategic patience necessary to solve its puzzles, or for its compelling themes of cosmic conflict and the possible rough edges of scientific discovery, one shall find satisfaction in Half-Life. The dozens of Vortigaunts, Headcrabs, and Alien Grunts are there to remind the player that different kinds of shooting and approaching are necessary in order to survive both Black Mesa and Xen. How far into the dimensions of suspense and cunning one can get - is up to the player's willingness to brave this gaming gemstone from the late 1990s.

When critiquing this game, one must bare in mind the age of this piece. A game that dates to a time when I was barely sentient will, unfortunately, mean that there is an abundance of dust that has collected on the proverbial shelves of the core aspects of this game. These eat away at the once prevallent polish of this game.

Despite this, I still find the game fun to play. One must admit, with the level of saturation prevallent in the FPS genre as of my writing this, that even this shooter has more brains than some modern shooters. At the very least, the community of people who actually still play this game regularly is far more mature than the modern shooter community.

With it's age accounted for, this is still an amazing game. It looked beautiful for the time, it had a great story, the characters were believable, the controlls were pertty good in comparison to other games from it's time, and I actually felt like I got something slightly different out of it each time I did another playthrough.

Today, the game is still rather solid. It still handles relatively well(aside for the ladders), and retains that great story and atmosphere. The pitfalls, when compared to modern games, is the ovbious graphical gap and severe lack of intelligence in the A.I. The animations aren't terrible, but I've seen someone do better with a flash game. It's still nice to play once in a blue moon for a nostalgia trip.

In short, don't expect this to be a ground breaking experience if you don't have any nostalgia towards it. You will probably still have fun with it if you're not so much of a graphics whore that you can't stand ps1-esque graphics.

9/10 - Great classic FPS that easily stands out, even among more recent shooters

Pros: Immersive story, plenty of action, wide variety of weapons, mild to moderate puzzles

Cons: It is very easy to take fall damage, ladder mechanic is hit-and-miss (you tend to fall alot while trying to use them), boosting platforms often result in death if you don't save and practice with them
Assolutamente si. Un cult, forse il miglior FPS di tutti i tempi.

My friend told me that no girls would ever like me so I fell into a spiraling depression. I went weeks without doing my homework or watching hentai which are usually my two favorite things to do so my parents knew something was wrong. They asked me if I was depressed and being the young alpha male I was I told them to fuck off and continued to throw myself down the stairs as I read on the internet that was the best way to kill myself. Weeks became months and it became aparant to my family that there was something wrong. They told me if I was going to kill myself I had to do it right, so they gave me two double A batterys and told me to eat them. I spent the whole day trying to crack those batterys open but it was just too hard and I was ready to give up on giving up on life but then my Dad shouted at me from across the hall "Gonah you fucking retard either kill yourself now or i'll fuck your mother in front of you!" That horrified me as I hated watching the video of my own contraception so much I knew I had to kill myself then. I quickly swallowed the two double A batterys whole and as I choked on the batterys and started to black out my father started to jerk off onto my writhing body. I ended up waking up in the hospital and the first thing I saw was a doctor leaning over me. I felt weird and clichely asked "what happend...?" to the docter. He said "Gonah i'm sorry to have to tell you this but you have been in a coma for 40 years. It's not all bad you still have Half of your Life left. It is when I heard that that I knew I had to play Half-Life.

Vale la pena comprarlo y creo que vale la pena el gasto de comprar la saga por paquete.

Fun and very challenging game. Has its quirks but is charming all the same. With unique storytelling and an immersive world, it is certainly a must-play. 

But it is certainly a late 90s game and must be treated accordingly. The later chapters can be rage-inducing, and the difficulty scaling seems exponential at times. Not impossible, but very difficult as you fight deeper and deeper into the compound. I've just survived critical points with 3% health more often than not after dying numerous times. 

PLAY THIS GAME ON WINDOWS XP! (Full backcompatability with operating systems usually isn't a thing) This game deserves to be fully supported by the platform it's on, and not messing with backcompatability makes the experience that much smoother.
